description.p: There are deities of good and deities of evil. Then there are those who decide that chance is the greatest mediator of good and evil. Clerics of the luck domain embrace this mediator, their holy symbols often reflect this, being playing cards or roulette balls.

description.p: You gain domain spells at the cleric levels listed in the Luck Domain Spells table. See the Divine Domain class feature for how domain spells work.
When you choose this domain at 1st level you gain proficiency in the gaming sets and improvised weapons

description.p: When you cast a spell that targets a friendly creature they have advantage on their next roll that requires a d20.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that targets a friendly creature they have advantage on their next roll that requires a d20.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level you start to get the hang of luck. When friendly creatures are forced to make a saving throw you can use your reaction to grant a number of creatures = your wisdom modifier advantage on the saving throw.

description.p: You score a critical hit on a 7 or 20 but a critical fail on a 13 or 1.

description.p: Starting at 8th level you add your Wisdom modifier to attack and damage rolls with improvised weapons. Additionally once per turn with an improvised weapon you can deal an additional 1d8, this increases to 2d8 at 14th level

Starting at 8th level you add {{wisdom:modifier}} to attack and damage rolls with improvised weapons. Additionally once per turn with an improvised weapon you can deal an additional 2d8

description.p: Starting at 17th level you can push your luck to the extreme. You can use your action once per long rest to use arcane roulette. Roll a 1d10 and the 9th level spell listed takes effect as if a cleric spell for you. You must choose a target before you roll.
